questions.question: The postmortem change seen in the image below corresponds to which of the following:
questions.explanation: Correct Ans: A Marbling: Marbling refers to the mottled appearance of blood vessels seen on the surface of the skin or internal organs due to the formation of blood clots after death. This change occurs as a result of the breakdown of blood cells and the settling of blood components. Marbling is commonly observed in the early stages of decomposition. Incorrect option: Option B . Algor mortis: Algor mortis refers to the cooling of the body after death. It is the gradual loss of body heat until the body reaches the ambient temperature. It is not directly associated with any visual changes on the body. Option C . Rigor mortis: Rigor mortis is the stiffening of the muscles after death due to the coagulation of muscle proteins. It is a temporary condition that usually starts within a few hours after death and resolves after 24 to 48 hours. Option D . Post mortem lividity: Post mortem lividity, also known as livor mortis, is the pooling or settling of blood in the dependent parts of the body after death. It results in a purplish or bluish discoloration of the skin in the lower areas due to gravity. Reference: .

questions.question: In a dead body, bloating of face, tongue protrusions were noted along with the findings in the image. Identify the phenomenon:
questions.explanation: including bloating of the face and other body parts, as well as tongue protrusion. Putrefaction Putrefaction is driven by bacterial activity, resulting in tissue breakdown and gas production. Characteristics of Putrefaction: Bacterial Involvement: Primarily caused by Clostridium perfringens. Lytic Enzyme: The main enzyme involved is lecithinase, which breaks down cell membranes. Stages of Putrefaction: Color Change: The first internal change is reddish-brown discoloration of the aortic intima. The first external change is green discoloration in the right iliac fossa due to the breakdown of hemoglobin. Mechanism of Color Change: Hydrogen Sulfide Production: Bacteria produce hydrogen sulfide, which forms a green compound with hemoglobin. The cecum is the primary site of discoloration due to high bacterial activity. Gas Formation: Gas production leads to bloating, with gases like carbon dioxide, methane, and hydrogen sulfide. Liquefaction of Tissue: Tissues become liquefied, losing structural integrity, contributing to the characteristic odor of decomposition. Timing of Discoloration: Discoloration begins within 12-18 hours in summer and 1-2 days in winter, influenced by temperature and bacterial activity. Electrocution & Crocodile burns (Option A & B) refers to the injury or death caused by an electric shock. It does not specifically result in bloating of the face, tongue protrusion, or putrefaction. Electrocution-related findings would typically involve specific burn patterns or injury marks associated with the electrical source. Crocodile burns are seen in high voltage electric burns. Scalds (Option C) are burns caused by contact with hot liquids or steam. Changes, such as blisters and skin peeling are seen. Scalds are acute injuries and do not involve postmortem processes Reference: Essentials of forensic medicine & Toxicology, K.S. Narayan Reddy, 35th Edition, Page 120-124. https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK539741/

questions.question: Identify the following post mortem change:
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Suggillation Explanation: Livor Mortis Other Names Postmortem staining, subcutaneous hypostasis, cadaveric lividity, suggillation , cogitation, vibices, and darkening of death. Definition Bluish or purplish-red discoloration caused by the gravitational settling of blood in the toneless capillaries and venules of the dependent parts of the dead body. Site Superficial layers of the dermis Mechanism Blood in capillaries and venules → Stagnates and sinks in dependent parts due to gravity → Bluish purple discoloration due to deoxy hemoglobin. Begins 0.5 - 1 hour Fully Developed Within 4 hours Fixation of Livor Mortis Typically, within 6-12 hours Confirmation of Fixation Apply thumb pressure against the skin for a few seconds → Blanching → Livor mortis not fixed. Primary Lividity Occurs as lividity reaches maximum intensity between 6 to 12 hours after death. Secondary Lividity Shifting of lividity can occur if the body is moved within a few hours after death. Duration of Persistence Staining persists until putrefaction begins. Distribution Depends on position of the body: Supine Appears on the back of neck, entire back, flanks, except areas under pressure (contact pallor). Prone Appears on the front part of the body. Side Appears on the dependent side. Head downwards Appears as a blackened face and neck. Vertical suspension Appears on legs and hands (glove and stocking appearance) and external genitalia. Drowning Appears on the face, upper chest, hands, lower arms, feet, and calves. Livor Mortis Absent Excessive blood loss Severe anemia Death from wasting diseases Lobar pneumonia Medicolegal Importance Helps estimate time of death. Indicates body posture at death. Indicates if the body was moved post-death. Distribution may indicate the cause of death. Image Tattooing (Option A) refers to the deposition of gunpowder particles on the skin when fired from a close distance. It creates small punctate marks around the entrance wound and is associated with firearm injuries , not a postmortem change. Putrefaction (Option C) refers to the decomposition of the body caused by bacterial activity, leading to the breakdown of tissues, gas formation, color changes, and a characteristic odor. This process occurs after death but is not the immediate postmortem change indicated in the question. Decomposition (Option D) occurs through autolysis (self-digestion by body enzymes) and putrefaction (bacterial breakdown, primarily by Clostridium perfringens ). Putrefaction involves

questions.question: In an autopsy of suspected poisoning, which organ, along with the stomach, part of the intestine, and liver, is preserved?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer A - Kidney In the context of a suspected poisoning autopsy, the kidney , along with the stomach, part of the intestine, and liver, is preserved for toxicological analysis. This is because the kidneys are essential for filtering toxins from the blood and can accumulate poisons, making them a valuable organ to analyze in cases of suspected poisoning. For toxicological analysis, various samples and organs should be preserved to identify poisoning or drug use. Blood : Collect venous blood (preferably from femoral, iliac, or axillary veins) in a tube with lithium heparin or EDTA, or fluoride/oxalate if alcohol is suspected. Vomit and Stomach Contents : Place in a clean glass jar or plastic tub with a tight-fitting lid. Feces : For heavy metal poisoning, collect 20-30g of rectal contents in a screw-topped jar or snap-on-lid container. Liver and Other Organs : Liver concentrates many drugs. Half the liver and gallbladder should be placed in a clean container. Bile may also be required for certain drug analyses (e.g., chlorpromazine, morphine). Hair and Nail Clippings : For heavy metal poisoning (e.g., arsenic, lead), collect hair pulled at the roots and nail clippings. These metals are detectable in keratin. Exhaled Air : Collected as required, with no preservative needed. Scene Residues : Collect relevant materials from the scene, such as tablets or containers, with no preservative. Other Organs and Specimens: Urine, sweat, saliva, spleen, kidneys , brain Lungs (Option B) : Not typically preserved unless the poisoning involves inhaled toxins. Muscle (Option C) : Not usually preserved unless there’s a specific reason, such as muscle breakdown from certain toxins. Heart (Option D) : Preserved only if there’s suspicion of cardiac involvement in the poisoning, but not a primary focus in most cases. Reference: Review of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, Gautam Biswas, 3rd Edition, Page 477, 478

questions.question: What is the first postmortem change that occurs in a dead body?

options.C: Greenish discoloration of right iliac fossa

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Greenish discoloration of right iliac fossa Explanation: Greenish discoloration of the right iliac fossa is the first postmortem change that happens, typically within 24–48 hours after death . It results from the breakdown of red blood cells and the release of hemoglobin, which reacts with the tissue and gives a greenish hue. The right iliac fossa is where the large intestine is located, and the green discoloration indicates the onset of decomposition, particularly the production of hydrogen sulfide by bacteria in the intestines. Decomposition: Decomposition is the biological process by which organic substances break down into simpler matter, critical for recycling nutrients in ecosystems. It occurs through two main mechanisms: Autolysis and Putrefaction. Autolysis Putrefaction Autolysis is the self-digestion of tissues caused by the body’s own enzymes after death. Characteristics of Autolysis: Initiation: Begins immediately after death when metabolic processes cease. Mechanism: Enzymatic action leads to cell lysis, altering tissue appearance and texture. Examples of Autolytic Changes: Clouding of the Cornea: The first observable external change, losing transparency due to cellular breakdown. Changes in Brain Glandular Tissue: The first internal change, where neuronal and glial cells undergo lysis. Note: Aseptic Autolysis: Occurs in intrauterine fetal demise, leading to mummification without bacterial involvement. Putrefaction is driven by bacterial activity, resulting in tissue breakdown and gas production. Characteristics of Putrefaction: Bacterial Involvement: Primarily caused by Clostridium perfringens. Lytic Enzyme: The main enzyme involved is lecithinase, which breaks down cell membranes. Stages of Putrefaction: Color Change: The first internal change is reddish-brown discoloration of the aortic intima. The first external change is green discoloration in the right iliac fossa due to the breakdown of hemoglobin. Mechanism of Color Change: Hydrogen Sulfide Production: Bacteria produce hydrogen sulfide, which forms a green compound with hemoglobin. The cecum is the primary site of discoloration due to high bacterial activity. Gas Formation: Gas production leads to bloating, with gases like carbon dioxide, methane, and hydrogen sulfide. Liquefaction of Tissue: Tissues become liquefied, losing structural integrity, contributing to the characteristic odor of decomposition. Timing of Discoloration: Discoloration begins within 12-18 hours in summer and 1-2 days in winter, influenced by temperature and bacterial activity. Incorrect Options: Maggot formation (Option A) occurs during the later stages of decomposition. Maggot infestation usually begins a few hours after death, but it's not the first change that happens in the body. This is a sign of decomposition, but it does not occur immediately after death. Putrefaction (Option B) is the process of decay caused by bacterial action, which begins a few hours after death. It leads to the breakdown of tissues and release of gases, causing bloating and a foul smell. While putrefaction is a significant postmortem change, it is not the first to occur. Mummification (Option D) occurs in specific environmental conditions, such as very dry climates, and involves the preservation of the body due to dehydration. It happens much later in the decomposition process and is not the first change after death. Reference: Essentials of forensic medicine & Toxicology, K.S. Narayan Reddy, 35th Edition, Page 120-124. https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK539741/

questions.question: Identify the postmortem change given in the following image.
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Marbling Explanation Marbling is a postmortem change characterized by a branching, vein-like pattern on the skin due to the breakdown of hemoglobin and bacterial proliferation (e.g., Clostridium welchii) within blood vessels. The discoloration results from the conversion of hemoglobin to sulfhemoglobin, producing a greenish-black appearance. Starts at 24 hours, visible between 36-48 hours. Helps in determining time since death. Tattooing (Option B): Tattooing refers to the deposition of gunpowder particles on the skin during close-range firearm discharge. It appears as punctate abrasions and is unrelated to postmortem decomposition. Lividity (Option C): Lividity, or postmortem hypostasis, is the pooling of blood in dependent areas of the body after death. It results in a purplish-red discoloration, but it lacks the branching pattern seen in marbling. Filigree burns (Option D): Filigree burns occur when an electrical current flows through the skin, creating a pattern that resembles lace or a branching network. It is a premortem finding, not a decomposition change. Learning Objective: Putrefaction Stimulated by bacterial activity (primarily Clostridium welchii or Clostridium perfringens). Three stages of change: Color change . Gas formation (producing bloating and distention). Liquefaction of tissues (softening and breakdown of tissues). Color changes: Green discoloration in the right iliac fossa due to hydrogen sulfide produced by bacteria. Starts in 12-18 hours in summer and 1-2 days in winter. Putrefaction sequence: Non-gravid uterus is the last organ to decompose in females. Prostrate is the last organ to decompose in males. Factors inhibiting Putrefaction ( Mnemonic CMS ): Strychinine Metallic poison ( Arsenic,Antimony,Thallium ) CO , Cyanide & Carbolic acid. Post-mortem luminescence: Emission of light from the body due to bacterial or fungal activity (e.g., Photobacteria and Armillaria).

questions.question: Study of death in all aspects is known as:
questions.explanation: Correct Answer A - Thanatology Thanatology deals with death in all aspects including somatic, systemic and clinical, and molecular or cellular death. Thanatology: Death and Dying : Examining the biological, physiological, and medical aspects of death, as well as the experiences, emotions, and psychological processes associated with dying. Bereavement and Grief: Investigating the psychological, emotional, and social responses to the loss of a loved one, including theories of grief, coping mechanisms, and support for individuals experiencing bereavement. End-of-Life Care: Exploring the ethical, legal, and practical considerations surrounding palliative care, hospice care, advance care planning, and the management of pain and symptoms in individuals nearing the end of life. Cultural and Religious Perspectives: Investigating how different cultures, religions, and belief systems understand and approach death, funeral rituals, mourning practices, and concepts of afterlife or spiritual continuity. Social and Legal Aspects: Examining the societal and legal frameworks surrounding death, including issues such as euthanasia, assisted suicide, funeral industry practices, organ donation, and legal rights and responsibilities related to death and dying. Forensic anthropology (Option B): Forensic anthropology involves the study of human remains. It involves applying the skeletal analysis, descriptive data, body marks, and photographs of the individual together to get to forensic inferences. Toxicology (Option C): Toxicology is the study of analysing suspect samples for the presence of toxins. It only deals with toxins that can be a cause of death- one aspect of death and not all of them. Molecular death (Option D): Molecular death is the death of cells and tissues individually. It occurs one to two hours after the stoppage of the vital functions. Reference: Thanatology

questions.question: Post-mortem examination of a dead body reveals contraction of the hands with absent primary relaxation. What is this suggestive of?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer C - Cadaveric spasm Cadaveric spasm (instantaneous rigor) is a rare postmortem phenomenon where the muscles stiffen immediately at the time of death without passing through the usual phase of primary muscular relaxation seen in typical rigor mortis. Key Features: Immediate onset: Occurs at the moment of death. Muscle groups affected: Usually involves small muscle groups, especially the hands and fingers. Violent deaths: Often associated with sudden, traumatic, or violent deaths. Emotional stress: Common in situations involving intense nervous tension before death, like drowning, suicides, or combat situations. Clenched fist: A classic sign , often seen when the deceased was holding an object firmly at death (e.g., weapon or grass in homicide). Rigor mortis (Option A): Involves a gradual stiffening of muscles, typically starting 2-6 hours after death, with a period of primary relaxation beforehand. Livor mortis (Option B): Postmortem lividity, where blood settles due to gravity, causing purple discoloration. Algor mortis (Option D): Is the cooling of the body after death. Reference: Cadaveric spasm

questions.question: A body brought for autopsy is cold and has developed rigor mortis in all 4 limbs and livor mortis at the back/fixed, but no signs of putrefaction. What will be the estimated time since death?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) 12–24 hours Explanation: The postmortem interval (PMI) estimation is based on a combination of algor mortis , rigor mortis , livor mortis , and putrefaction findings: Findings in This Case: Observation Interpretation Body cold to touch Suggests death occurred more than 8–12 hours ago (body cools gradually) Rigor mortis in all four limbs Fully established rigor occurs around 12 hours post-death and lasts up to 24 hrs Livor mortis fixed at the back Lividity becomes fixed after 6–12 hours No signs of putrefaction Putrefaction usually begins after 24–36 hours , depending on environment Given that: Rigor mortis is fully developed ( 12 hours ), Livor mortis is fixed ( ~8–12 hours ), No putrefaction is seen (<24–36 hours), The most accurate estimate for time since death is 12–24 hours. Livor Mortis Feature Details Other names Cadaveric lividity, postmortem staining, suggillations, vibices, "darkening of death" Site Superficial dermis (capillaries and venules) Mechanism Gravitational settling of deoxygenated blood → purple-blue skin discolouration in dependent areas Onset Begins in 30 minutes – 1 hour after death Fully developed by ~ 4 hours Fixation time Becomes fixed in 6–12 hours Confirmation of fixation Apply pressure → if colour does not blanch, it is fixed Primary lividity Max intensity seen by 6–12 hours Secondary lividity Lividity may shift if the body is moved within a few hours of death Duration Persists until putrefaction begins Image The progression of rigor mortis can be divided into three main phases. Phase Description Timeframe Primary Relaxation Muscles are flaccid; ATP levels are 100%. Sphincters relax, leading to the release of urine/feces. 0–1 hour after death Rigor Mortis Onset Begins as ATP falls to 85%; actin-myosin cross-linking causes stiffening. Appears in smaller muscles first (eyelids, jaw), progresses to limbs. Begins 1–2 hrs; full by 12 hrs Rigor Resolution Due to proteolysis, rigidity dissipates. Rigor fades by 24–36 hours depending on conditions. 12–36 hours after death Position Lividity Location Supine Back of head, neck, trunk, and limbs (excluding pressure areas) Prone Chest, face, front of limbs Side Dependent side Head-down Face and neck blackened Vertical suspension Legs, hands, external genitalia (glove and stocking pattern) Drowning Face, chest, hands, feet, calves Conditions Where Livor Mortis May Be Absent: Severe anaemia Massive blood loss Cachexia (wasting diseases) Some infections like lobar pneumonia Medicolegal Significance of Livor Mortis: Helps estimate time since death Indicates body position at death Suggests if the body was moved postmortem May hint at cause of death (e.g., cherry-red lividity in CO poisoning)

questions.question: Which of the following is true regarding adipocere formation?
questions.explanation: is a process where body fat turns into a waxy substance due to saponification. This process involves the hydrolysis of fats in the body by bacteria, leading to the formation of a soapy, wax-like substance that helps in the preservation of the body. Incorrect Options: Option B - High temperature needed: Adipocere formation generally occurs in a cool, moist environment. High temperatures are not conducive to this process; rather, the process is enhanced in cooler conditions which slow down decomposition and support the saponification process. Option C - Cool and dry climate needed: While a cool climate can favor adipocere formation, a dry climate is not ideal. Adipocere formation requires moisture to facilitate the saponification process. Therefore, a cool and moist environment is more conducive to adipocere formation. Option D - Occurs within minutes to hours: Adipocere formation is a relatively slow process that can take several weeks to months to develop fully, not minutes to hours. Reference: .

questions.question: Which of the following eye signs can be appreciated in the image?
questions.explanation: appears as a triangular area of cell debris and mucus, with color changes from yellow to brown or black after 3 to 6 hours of death. questions.question: Cadaveric spasm is seen in death due to all of the following except?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Traumatic asphyxia Explanation: Traumatic asphyxia typically results from external compression of the chest, leading to venous congestion and petechial hemorrhages. It does not typically cause cadaveric spasm as the mechanism of death is slower compared to the instantaneous deaths associated with cadaveric spasm. Incorrect Options: Suicidal gun-shot wound (Option A): Cadaveric spasm can occur in individuals who commit suicide by gunshot, particularly if they were holding the weapon at the time of death. The intense emotional state and instantaneous death may lead to this phenomenon. Electrocution (Option B): Cadaveric spasm is often observed in electrocution cases due to the immediate and intense contraction of muscles caused by the electric current and tight grasping of electric wire. Drowning (Option C): In cases of drowning, cadaveric spasm may involve the hands tightly clutching weeds, mud, or other objects in the water, indicating a struggle before death. Reference: Knight’s Forensic Pathology Pg no: 62-65

questions.question: The method of autopsy carried out en masse to remove from the tongue to the prostate is:
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Letulle technique Explanation Letulle technique is named after Maurice Letulle which involves the removal of organs together in one mass from tongue to prostate Methods of Autopsy 1. Virchow’s Method (M/C) One-by-one organ removal. (Option A ruled out) Fast and easy. Typically used for general autopsies. 2. Ghon’s/en-Block Method Targeted organ removal (Cervical, Thoracic, Abdominal, Pelvic blocks). (Option C ruled out) Organ relations remain intact. Thoracic block for chest-related issues, pelvic block for sexual assaults. Useful when preserving inter-organ relationships . 3. Lettule’s/en-Masses/Evisceration (Option D) Large masses of organs removed together (C+T+A+P). Complete viscera removal. Blood vessels and vascular supply intact. Suitable for minor bleeding cases. 4. Rokitansky/In-situ Method (Option B ruled out) Inside dissection. Used in infectious diseases (HIV, Hepatitis, COVID-19) . Highly transmissible diseases. Also used for infants <1 year to minimize contamination risk. Reference: https://documents-cloud.cap.org/estore/pdf/PUB119_IntroAutopsy_Sample.pdf

Lettule’s/en-Masses/Evisceration (Option B ruled out) Large masses of organs removed together (C+T+A+P). Complete viscera removal. Blood vessels and vascular supply intact. Suitable for minor bleeding cases. 4. Rokitansky/In-situ Method (Option D) Inside dissection. Used in infectious diseases (HIV, Hepatitis, COVID-19) . Highly transmissible diseases. questions.question: The temperature of the body of a deceased person is found to be 39°C. Which of the following is the most probable reason?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Septicemia Explanation Septicemia, which is a systemic infection with widespread inflammation, is a common cause of fever in both living and deceased individuals. It can cause hyperthermia due to the body's inflammatory response. Elevated body temperature within the first two hours after death points toward a diagnosis of Postmortem caloricity. Postmortem Caloricity: Refers to the condition where the body temperature remains elevated for the first two hours after death. Causes of Postmortem Caloricity: 1. Disturbed heat regulation 2. Increased heat production (excessive muscle contraction) 3. Excessive bacterial activity Sunstroke Pontine hemorrhage Tetanus Strychnine poisoning Septicaemia Cholera Note: Burns do not typically cause postmortem caloricity. Incorrect Options: Cyanide poisoning (Option A): Cyanide poisoning typically causes rapid death and may lead to hypothermia rather than fever. Cyanide inhibits cellular respiration, leading to metabolic acidosis, but does not usually result in a fever like septicemia. Corrosive poisoning (Option C): Corrosive poisoning (e.g., acid or alkali ingestion) can cause significant damage to tissues, but it does not typically result in a high body temperature like 39°C. It might lead to shock and other complications, but fever is not the hallmark sign. Intra-abdominal hemorrhage (Option D): Intra-abdominal hemorrhage typically results in hypovolemic shock due to blood loss, leading to low body temperature (hypothermia) rather than fever. Reference: Review of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, Gautam Biswas, 3rd Edition, Page 139 Essentials of forensic medicine & Toxicology, K.S. Narayan Reddy, 35th Edition, Page 114

questions.question: The most reliable criteria among Gustafson's criteria for age estimation is ?
questions.explanation: especially in forensic odontology. Gustafson's technique , developed by Gustafson in 1950, is a widely used method for age estimation in adults based on dental characteristics . Among Gustafson's criteria, the most reliable criterion for age estimation is the translucency of the root (Option C). The technique involves attributing scores for various age-related changes observed in teeth, such as attrition, periodontal ligament retractions, secondary dentin formations, root translucency, and root resorption. The translucency of the root is considered one of the most reliable indicators of age , as it gradually increases with age due to the deposition of secondary dentin and changes in the root structure . Incorrect Options: Option A, B & D - Root resorption, Paradentosis & Attrition: While these criteria are also considered in Gustafson's technique, the translucency of the root is considered the most reliable indicator of age estimation among Gustafson's criteria. Reference: Prepladder Notes

questions.question: What is the odor of the mummified body ?
questions.explanation: desiccation of a dead body, resulting in the preservation of its natural appearances and features through evaporation of water. Here are the key points about mummification: Definition: Rapid dehydration and desiccation of the body, preserving its natural appearance. Modification of putrefaction: Mummification is a form of dry decomposition, distinct from the wet decomposition seen in putrefaction. Physical changes: The entire body loses weight, becomes thin, stiff, and brittle. It also becomes odorless. Prevention of decomposition: The process of normal decomposition, which involves the growth of microorganisms, is prevented or significantly retarded in mummification. This is due to the rapid dehydration and lack of moisture, which inhibits microbial growth. Incorrect Options: Option B - Pungent: This option is not correct. A pungent odor refers to a strong, sharp, and often unpleasant smell. It is not typically associated with a mummified body, as the process of mummification involves the preservation of the body and the prevention of decomposition. Option C - Putrid: This option is not correct. The term "putrid" refers to a foul or rotten smell associated with decomposition. A mummified body does not have a putrid odor because the mummification process hinders decomposition. Option D - Offensive: This option is not correct. An offensive odor refers to a strong, unpleasant, and offensive smell. Similar to the previous options, a mummified body does not have an offensive odor due to the preservation process that prevents decomposition. Reference: Prepladder Notes

questions.question: Which of the following is commonly used for preservation of viscera in toxicology autopsy ?
questions.explanation: preservation of viscera in toxicology autopsy. It is a hypertonic solution that helps to prevent decomposition and maintain the integrity of the tissues for further toxicological analysis. The high salt concentration creates an osmotic environment that inhibits bacterial growth and enzymatic degradation. Various methods of preserving viscera: Saturated salt solution Formalin fixation Freezing Alcohol preservation Formaldehyde solution Formalin-alcohol solution Frozen section Liquid nitrogen Incorrect Options: Option A - Glycerin: Glycerin is not commonly used for the preservation of viscera in toxicology autopsy. It may have some disinfectant properties but is not suitable for long-term tissue preservation. questions.question: Paradoxical undressing is seen in :
questions.explanation: Correct Ans: C Paradoxical undressing is a phenomenon that can occur in cases of severe hypothermia. When a person is experiencing extreme cold and their core body temperature drops significantly, paradoxical undressing refers to the behaviour of the individual inexplicably removing their clothing, often resulting in being found partially or completely naked. Peripheral vasoconstriction caused by cold temperatures may also contribute to discomfort, leading to clothing removal. Incorrect option: Option A . Heart stress: Heart stress, also known as cardiac stress or cardiac strain, refers to excessive strain or demand placed on the heart. It is not associated with paradoxical undressing. Option B. Voyeurism: Voyeurism is a paraphilic disorder characterized by deriving sexual pleasure from observing others without their consent. It is unrelated to paradoxical undressing. Option D. LSD overdose: LSD (Lysergic acid diethylamide) is a hallucinogenic drug, and an overdose of LSD can lead to various physiological and psychological effects. However, paradoxical undressing is not a recognized symptom or consequence of LSD overdose.
